1.title: Building an understanding of how drivers interact with emerging vehicle technologies
1.sub_heading: The MIT Advanced Vehicle Technology Consortium provides data-driven insights into driver behavior, along with trust in AI and advance vehicle technology.
1.author: Benjy Kantor | MIT Center for Transportation and Logistics
1.summary: The MIT Advanced Vehicle Technology Consortium analyzes driver interactions with new vehicle technologies, offering data-driven insights into behavior and trust levels in AI and advanced vehicle systems. Their research aims to enhance the understanding of how these technologies influence driver experience and safety.

2.title: A vision for U.S. science success
2.sub_heading: In a talk at MIT, White House science advisor Arati Prabhakar outlined challenges in medicine, climate, and AI, while expressing resolve to tackle hard problems.
2.author: Peter Dizikes | MIT News
2.summary: In her talk at MIT, White House science advisor Arati Prabhakar highlighted the challenges facing the U.S. in medicine, climate change, and artificial intelligence, emphasizing a commitment to addressing these complex issues head-on.

3.title: MIT researchers develop an efficient way to train more reliable AI agents
3.sub_heading: The technique could make AI systems better at complex tasks that involve variability.
3.author: Adam Zewe | MIT News
3.summary: MIT researchers have created a new method to train AI agents more efficiently, enhancing their reliability in handling complex tasks with variable conditions. This advancement aims to improve the overall performance and adaptability of AI systems.

4.title: Advancing urban tree monitoring with AI-powered digital twins
4.sub_heading: The Tree-D Fusion system integrates generative AI and genus-conditioned algorithms to create precise simulation-ready models of 600,000 existing urban trees across North America.
4.author: Rachel Gordon | MIT CSAIL
4.summary: The Tree-D Fusion system uses AI and specialized algorithms to develop accurate digital models of 600,000 urban trees in North America, enhancing urban tree monitoring and management. This integration of generative AI allows for detailed simulations and better understanding of urban forestry dynamics.

5.title: A model of virtuosity
5.sub_heading: Acclaimed keyboardist Jordan Rudess’s collaboration with the MIT Media Lab culminates in live improvisation between an AI “jam_bot” and the artist.
5.author: Nicole Estvanik Taylor | Arts at MIT
5.summary: Acclaimed keyboardist Jordan Rudess collaborates with the MIT Media Lab to create a live improvisational experience featuring an AI "jam_bot" that interacts with his performances. This innovative partnership showcases the fusion of human creativity and artificial intelligence in music.

6.title: Can robots learn from machine dreams?
6.sub_heading: MIT CSAIL researchers used AI-generated images to train a robot dog in parkour, without real-world data. Their LucidSim system demonstrates generative AI's potential for creating robotics training data.
6.author: Rachel Gordon | MIT CSAIL
6.summary: MIT CSAIL researchers developed LucidSim, a system that uses AI-generated images to train a robot dog in parkour, showcasing how generative AI can create effective training data without relying on real-world examples. This approach highlights the innovative potential of machine dreams in advancing robotics.

7.title: Four from MIT named 2025 Rhodes Scholars
7.sub_heading: Yiming Chen ’24, Wilhem Hector, Anushka Nair, and David Oluigbo will start postgraduate studies at Oxford next fall.
7.author: Julia Mongo | Distinguished Fellowships
7.summary: Four MIT students—Yiming Chen, Wilhem Hector, Anushka Nair, and David Oluigbo—have been selected as 2025 Rhodes Scholars and will begin their postgraduate studies at Oxford next fall.

8.title: Ensuring a durable transition
8.sub_heading: Progress on the energy transition depends on collective action benefiting all stakeholders, agreed participants in MITEI’s annual research conference.
8.author: Leda Zimmerman | MIT Energy Initiative
8.summary: Participants at MITEI's annual research conference emphasized that a successful energy transition relies on collaborative efforts that consider the needs of all stakeholders involved. They highlighted the importance of collective action in achieving sustainable progress.

9.title: Graph-based AI model maps the future of innovation
9.sub_heading: An AI method developed by Professor Markus Buehler finds hidden links between science and art to suggest novel materials.
9.author: Stephanie Martinovich | Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering
9.summary: Professor Markus Buehler's graph-based AI model uncovers hidden connections between science and art, paving the way for innovative material discoveries. This approach aims to inspire novel applications and advancements in various fields.

10.title: 3 Questions: Inverting the problem of design
10.sub_heading: MIT and IBM researchers are creating linkage mechanisms to innovate human-AI kinematic engineering.
10.author: Lauren Hinkel | MIT-IBM Watson AI Lab

11.title: A causal theory for studying the cause-and-effect relationships of genes
11.sub_heading: By sidestepping the need for costly interventions, a new method could potentially reveal gene regulatory programs, paving the way for targeted treatments.
11.author: Adam Zewe | MIT News

12.title: A portable light system that can digitize everyday objects
12.sub_heading: A new design tool uses UV and RGB lights to change the color and textures of everyday objects. The system could enable surfaces to display dynamic patterns, such as health data and fashion designs.
12.author: Alex Shipps | MIT CSAIL
12.summary: A new portable light system utilizes UV and RGB lights to digitize everyday objects, allowing surfaces to exhibit dynamic colors and textures. This innovative design tool could transform how we interact with items by displaying information like health data and fashion designs.

13.title: Despite its impressive output, generative AI doesn’t have a coherent understanding of the world
13.sub_heading: Researchers show that even the best-performing large language models don’t form a true model of the world and its rules, and can thus fail unexpectedly on similar tasks.
13.author: Adam Zewe | MIT News
13.summary: Generative AI, despite its strong performance, lacks a true understanding of the world and its rules, leading to unexpected failures on similar tasks, as highlighted by researchers. This indicates that even advanced language models do not form coherent mental models of reality.

14.title: Empowering systemic racism research at MIT and beyond
14.sub_heading: Researchers in the MIT Initiative on Combatting Systemic Racism are building an open data repository to advance research on racial inequity in domains like policing, housing, and health care.
14.author: Scott Murray | Institute for Data, Systems, and Society
14.summary: The MIT Initiative on Combatting Systemic Racism is creating an open data repository to support research on racial inequities in areas such as policing, housing, and health care. This effort aims to empower scholars and advocates in their fight against systemic racism.

15.title: Artist and designer Es Devlin awarded Eugene McDermott Award in the Arts at MIT
15.sub_heading: Exploring biodiversity, linguistic diversity, and collective AI-generated poetry, her work will be honored with a $100K prize, artist residency, and public lecture at MIT in spring 2025.
15.author: Leah Talatinian | Arts at MIT
15.summary: Es Devlin has been awarded the Eugene McDermott Award in the Arts at MIT, recognizing her work that delves into biodiversity, linguistic diversity, and collective AI-generated poetry. The honor includes a $100K prize, an artist residency, and a public lecture scheduled for spring 2025.

16.title: Nanoscale transistors could enable more efficient electronics
16.sub_heading: Researchers are leveraging quantum mechanical properties to overcome the limits of silicon semiconductor technology.
16.author: Adam Zewe | MIT News
16.summary: Researchers are exploring nanoscale transistors that utilize quantum mechanical properties to enhance the efficiency of electronics, potentially surpassing the limitations of traditional silicon semiconductor technology. This advancement could lead to significant improvements in electronic device performance.

17.title: MIT Schwarzman College of Computing launches postdoctoral program to advance AI across disciplines
17.sub_heading: The new Tayebati Postdoctoral Fellowship Program will support leading postdocs to bring cutting-edge AI to bear on research in scientific discovery or music.
17.author: Terri Park | MIT Schwarzman College of Computing
17.summary: MIT's Schwarzman College of Computing has introduced the Tayebati Postdoctoral Fellowship Program to foster interdisciplinary research by supporting postdocs who will apply advanced AI techniques to fields like scientific discovery and music. This initiative aims to enhance the integration of AI across various disciplines.

18.title: A faster, better way to train general-purpose robots
18.sub_heading: Inspired by large language models, researchers develop a training technique that pools diverse data to teach robots new skills.
18.author: Adam Zewe | MIT News
18.summary: Researchers have developed a new training technique for general-purpose robots that draws inspiration from large language models, utilizing a diverse data pool to enhance skill acquisition and improve training efficiency. This approach aims to accelerate the learning process for robots, making them more versatile in their tasks.

19.title: Making it easier to verify an AI model’s responses
19.sub_heading: By allowing users to clearly see data referenced by a large language model, this tool speeds manual validation to help users spot AI errors.
19.author: Adam Zewe | MIT News
19.summary: A new tool enhances the verification of AI model responses by allowing users to easily access the data referenced by large language models, facilitating quicker manual validation and enabling users to identify errors more effectively.

20.title: Combining next-token prediction and video diffusion in computer vision and robotics
20.sub_heading: A new method can train a neural network to sort corrupted data while anticipating next steps. It can make flexible plans for robots, generate high-quality video, and help AI agents navigate digital environments.
20.author: Alex Shipps | MIT CSAIL
20.summary: A new method integrates next-token prediction with video diffusion, enabling neural networks to sort corrupted data and make flexible plans for robots. This approach enhances AI capabilities in generating high-quality video and navigating digital environments.

21.title: Equipping doctors with AI co-pilots
21.sub_heading: Alumni-founded Ambience Healthcare automates routine tasks for clinicians before, during, and after patient visits.
21.author: Zach Winn | MIT News
21.summary: Ambience Healthcare, founded by alumni, develops AI co-pilots that streamline routine tasks for doctors before, during, and after patient visits, enhancing efficiency in clinical settings.

22.title: Artificial intelligence meets “blisk” in new DARPA-funded collaboration
22.sub_heading: Collaborative multi-university team will pursue new AI-enhanced design tools and high-throughput testing methods for next-generation turbomachinery.
22.author: Janine Liberty | Anne Wilson | Department of Aeronautics and Astronautics | Department of Mechanical Engineering
22.summary: A multi-university team, funded by DARPA, is developing AI-enhanced design tools and high-throughput testing methods aimed at advancing next-generation turbomachinery. This collaboration combines artificial intelligence with innovative design approaches to improve efficiency and performance in the field.

23.title: Modeling relationships to solve complex problems efficiently
23.sub_heading: Associate Professor Julian Shun develops high-performance algorithms and frameworks for large-scale graph processing.
23.author: Adam Zewe | MIT News
23.summary: Associate Professor Julian Shun focuses on creating high-performance algorithms and frameworks to enhance the efficiency of large-scale graph processing, leveraging relationship modeling to tackle complex problems. His work aims to improve how we handle intricate data structures in various applications.

24.title: How AI is improving simulations with smarter sampling techniques
24.sub_heading: MIT CSAIL researchers created an AI-powered method for low-discrepancy sampling, which uniformly distributes data points to boost simulation accuracy.
24.author: Rachel Gordon | MIT CSAIL
24.summary: MIT CSAIL researchers developed an AI-driven approach for low-discrepancy sampling that enhances simulation accuracy by uniformly distributing data points. This method improves the quality of simulations by optimizing how data is sampled.

25.title: Q&A: A new initiative to help strengthen democracy
25.sub_heading: David Singer, head of the MIT Department of Political Science, discusses the Strengthening Democracy Initiative, focused on the rigorous study of elections, public opinion, and political participation.
25.author: Department of Political Science
25.summary: David Singer, head of MIT's Political Science Department, discusses the Strengthening Democracy Initiative, which aims to enhance democracy through in-depth research on elections, public opinion, and political engagement. The initiative seeks to provide insights that can inform better democratic practices and foster greater civic participation.

26.title: AI simulation gives people a glimpse of their potential future self
26.sub_heading: By enabling users to chat with an older version of themselves, Future You is aimed at reducing anxiety and guiding young people to make better choices.
26.author: Adam Zewe | MIT News
26.summary: The AI simulation "Future You" allows individuals to converse with an older version of themselves, helping to alleviate anxiety and encourage better decision-making among young people by providing insights into their potential future.

27.title: AI pareidolia: Can machines spot faces in inanimate objects?
27.sub_heading: New dataset of “illusory” faces reveals differences between human and algorithmic face detection, links to animal face recognition, and a formula predicting where people most often perceive faces.
27.author: Rachel Gordon | MIT CSAIL
27.summary: The article discusses a new dataset on AI pareidolia, which examines how machines and humans detect faces in inanimate objects, revealing differences in their recognition abilities. It also explores connections to animal face recognition and presents a formula that predicts common locations where people perceive faces.

28.title: Helping robots zero in on the objects that matter
28.sub_heading: A new method called Clio enables robots to quickly map a scene and identify the items they need to complete a given set of tasks.
28.author: Jennifer Chu | MIT News
28.summary: A new method called Clio enhances robots' ability to efficiently map their surroundings and pinpoint essential objects needed for specific tasks. This advancement streamlines robotic functionality in various applications.

29.title: MIT launches new Music Technology and Computation Graduate Program
29.sub_heading: The program will invite students to investigate new vistas at the intersection of music, computing, and technology.
29.author: Benjamin Daniel | School of Humanities, Arts, and Social Sciences
29.summary: MIT has introduced a new graduate program in Music Technology and Computation, encouraging students to explore innovative areas where music, computing, and technology converge.

30.title: New security protocol shields data from attackers during cloud-based computation
30.sub_heading: The technique leverages quantum properties of light to guarantee security while preserving the accuracy of a deep-learning model.
30.author: Adam Zewe | MIT News
30.summary: A new security protocol utilizes the quantum properties of light to protect data during cloud-based computation, ensuring robust security without compromising the accuracy of deep-learning models.

31.title: Fifteen Lincoln Laboratory technologies receive 2024 R&D 100 Awards
31.sub_heading: The innovations map the ocean floor and the brain, prevent heat stroke and cognitive injury, expand AI processing and quantum system capabilities, and introduce new fabrication approaches.
31.author: Kylie Foy | MIT Lincoln Laboratory
31.summary: Fifteen technologies from Lincoln Laboratory were honored with 2024 R&D 100 Awards for innovations that include mapping the ocean floor and brain, preventing heat stroke and cognitive injuries, enhancing AI processing and quantum systems, and introducing novel fabrication methods. These advancements showcase significant contributions across various fields of research and technology.

32.title: 3 Questions: Should we label AI systems like we do prescription drugs?
32.sub_heading: Researchers argue that in health care settings, “responsible use” labels could ensure AI systems are deployed appropriately.
32.author: Adam Zewe | MIT News

33.title: Accelerating particle size distribution estimation
33.sub_heading: MIT researchers speed up a novel AI-based estimator for medication manufacturing by 60 times.
33.author: Anne Wilson | Department of Mechanical Engineering
33.summary: MIT researchers have developed an AI-based estimator that accelerates the particle size distribution estimation process for medication manufacturing, achieving a speed increase of 60 times compared to previous methods. This advancement could significantly enhance the efficiency of pharmaceutical production.

34.title: New AI JetPack accelerates the entrepreneurial process
34.sub_heading: The digital adviser helps users swiftly navigate the 24-step “Disciplined Entrepreneurship” process.
34.author: Meredith Somers | MIT Sloan School of Management
34.summary: The New AI JetPack streamlines the entrepreneurial journey by guiding users through the 24-step "Disciplined Entrepreneurship" framework, making the process faster and more efficient. This digital adviser enhances decision-making for aspiring entrepreneurs.

35.title: AI model can reveal the structures of crystalline materials
35.sub_heading: By analyzing X-ray crystallography data, the model could help researchers develop new materials for many applications, including batteries and magnets.
35.author: Anne Trafton | MIT News
35.summary: An AI model that analyzes X-ray crystallography data can uncover the structures of crystalline materials, potentially aiding researchers in creating new materials for various applications like batteries and magnets.

36.title: Study: AI could lead to inconsistent outcomes in home surveillance
36.sub_heading: Researchers find large language models make inconsistent decisions about whether to call the police when analyzing surveillance videos.
36.author: Adam Zewe | MIT News
36.summary: A study reveals that AI systems, particularly large language models, may produce inconsistent results in home surveillance scenarios, leading to varying decisions on whether to alert law enforcement based on analyzed footage. This inconsistency raises concerns about the reliability of AI in critical safety applications.

37.title: Enhancing LLM collaboration for smarter, more efficient solutions
37.sub_heading: “Co-LLM” algorithm helps a general-purpose AI model collaborate with an expert large language model by combining the best parts of both answers, leading to more factual responses.
37.author: Alex Shipps | MIT CSAIL
37.summary: The "Co-LLM" algorithm improves collaboration between a general-purpose AI model and an expert large language model, effectively merging their strengths to produce more accurate and factual responses. This approach aims to create smarter and more efficient solutions in AI interactions.

38.title: A fast and flexible approach to help doctors annotate medical scans
38.sub_heading: “ScribblePrompt” is an interactive AI framework that can efficiently highlight anatomical structures across different medical scans, assisting medical workers to delineate regions of interest and abnormalities.
38.author: Alex Shipps | MIT CSAIL
38.summary: ScribblePrompt is an interactive AI framework designed to assist doctors in annotating medical scans by efficiently highlighting anatomical structures and delineating regions of interest and abnormalities. This fast and flexible tool aims to enhance the accuracy and speed of medical imaging analysis.

39.title: Study: Transparency is often lacking in datasets used to train large language models
39.sub_heading: Researchers developed an easy-to-use tool that enables an AI practitioner to find data that suits the purpose of their model, which could improve accuracy and reduce bias.
39.author: Adam Zewe | MIT News
39.summary: Researchers found that datasets used for training large language models often lack transparency, prompting the development of a user-friendly tool that helps AI practitioners identify suitable data, potentially enhancing model accuracy and minimizing bias.

40.title: A framework for solving parabolic partial differential equations
40.sub_heading: A new algorithm solves complicated partial differential equations by breaking them down into simpler problems, potentially guiding computer graphics and geometry processing.
40.author: Alex Shipps | MIT CSAIL
40.summary: A new algorithm for solving parabolic partial differential equations simplifies complex problems by breaking them down into more manageable parts, which could have significant applications in computer graphics and geometry processing.

41.title: First AI + Education Summit is an international push for “AI fluency”
41.sub_heading: The three-day, hands-on conference hosted by the MIT RAISE Initiative welcomed youths and adults from nearly 30 countries.
41.author: Andrew Whitacre | RAISE Initiative
41.summary: The First AI + Education Summit, organized by the MIT RAISE Initiative, brought together participants of all ages from nearly 30 countries for a three-day, interactive event focused on fostering "AI fluency." The summit aimed to enhance understanding and skills related to artificial intelligence in education.

42.title: 3 Questions: How to prove humanity online
42.sub_heading: AI agents could soon become indistinguishable from humans online. Could “personhood credentials” protect people against digital imposters?
42.author: Adam Zewe | MIT News
42.summary: The article discusses the potential for AI agents to become indistinguishable from humans online and explores the concept of "personhood credentials" as a way to safeguard individuals from digital impersonation. It raises questions about how to establish and verify human identity in an increasingly automated digital landscape.

43.title: New open-source tool helps to detangle the brain
43.sub_heading: The software tool NeuroTrALE is designed to quickly and efficiently process large amounts of brain imaging data semi-automatically.
43.author: Anne McGovern | MIT Lincoln Laboratory
43.summary: NeuroTrALE is a new open-source software tool that streamlines the processing of extensive brain imaging data in a semi-automated manner, aiding researchers in better understanding brain complexities.

44.title: MIT researchers use large language models to flag problems in complex systems
44.sub_heading: The approach can detect anomalies in data recorded over time, without the need for any training.
44.author: Adam Zewe | MIT News
44.summary: MIT researchers have developed a method using large language models to identify anomalies in complex systems by analyzing time-series data, eliminating the need for prior training. This innovative approach enhances the detection of issues in various data-driven environments.

45.title: Dimitris Bertsimas named vice provost for open learning
45.sub_heading: Leveraging more than 35 years of experience at MIT, Bertsimas will work with partners across the Institute to transform teaching and learning on and off campus.
45.author: Sara Feijo | MIT Open Learning

46.title: Precision home robots learn with real-to-sim-to-real
46.sub_heading: CSAIL researchers introduce a novel approach allowing robots to be trained in simulations of scanned home environments, paving the way for customized household automation accessible to anyone.
46.author: Rachel Gordon | MIT CSAIL

47.title: Method prevents an AI model from being overconfident about wrong answers
47.sub_heading: More efficient than other approaches, the “Thermometer” technique could help someone know when they should trust a large language model.
47.author: Adam Zewe | MIT News

48.title: Study: When allocating scarce resources with AI, randomization can improve fairness
48.sub_heading: Introducing structured randomization into decisions based on machine-learning model predictions can address inherent uncertainties while maintaining efficiency.
48.author: Adam Zewe | MIT News

49.title: Proton-conducting materials could enable new green energy technologies
49.sub_heading: Analysis and materials identified by MIT engineers could lead to more energy-efficient fuel cells, electrolyzers, batteries, or computing devices.
49.author: David L. Chandler | MIT News

50.title: Large language models don’t behave like people, even though we may expect them to
50.sub_heading: A new study shows someone’s beliefs about an LLM play a significant role in the model’s performance and are important for how it is deployed.
50.author: Adam Zewe | MIT News
